awd_titl_txt: Academic Workshops for Underrepresented Participants in Computing
awd_abstract_narration:
The Academic Career Mentoring Workshop series targets faculty (assistant professors and associate professors), senior graduate students, and postdoctoral researchers in computing from the following underrepresented groups: African American, Hispanic, Native American, and People with Disabilities.  The series started in 2005 and has been funded by NSF grants from 2007 through 2017.

The project will involve the following activities:
Organize workshops for 2018 through 2020; for each workshop, conduct a thorough evaluation of the workshop; leverage the workshop attendees and the newly-formed FLIP (Diversifying Future Leadership in the Professoriate) Alliance to extend the annual evaluation to consider the factors that influence the decisions to pursue academic careers; and at the end of the project, conduct a longitudinal evaluation of the program for 2010 through 2020.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering
org_div_long_name: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: Computer Science for All (CS for All)

por.por_cntn:
You know, 10 years ago when I started my journey and when I was ready to graduate, I wish I had someone tell me all the things that we learned here [ACW]. It would have made my life much easier than it was. It really is a privilege to have access to this. And I'm really grateful that you all put in the time and energy. It's very clear that you thought about what is useful for people as they are moving in different stages of their careers. -2024 ACW participant

The Academic Careers Mentoring Workshop Series was designed to provide support for under-represented ethnic minorities and people with disabilities at the level of assistant professor, associate professor, post-doctoral researcher and senior doctoral student.  The workshops focus on the promotion and tenure process, effective teaching, launching a research program, proposal writing, and funding opportunities.  Pre and post workshop survey questions asked participants about perceptions of their knowledge about the tenure and promotion process, obtaining funding, networking for career enhancement, and their abilities associated with identifying an academic mentor.  Below are results from the 2024 ACW, but the results are indicative of prior workshops.


Promotion & Tenure Process, Teaching, Launching Research Program

 Overall analysis of participant responses suggested that prior to the workshop participants as a group rated themselves inadequate to adequate on factors associated with the academic ladder specifically addressed at this workshop. Mean ratings ranged from 2.00 (knowledge about the promotion process) and 2.16 (regarding knowledge about obtaining funding) to 3.47 regarding the ability to teach effectively.  The mean ratings in the other areas ranged from 3.00 to 3.16. After the workshop mean ratings ranged from 3.94 regarding the ability to develop a focused research program, 4.13 regarding knowledge about the promotion process, and 4.18 the ability to teach effectively to 4.39 regarding knowledge the tenure process.   The mean ratings in the other areas now ranged from 4.18 to 4.58. The post workshop survey revealed increases in perceived level of adequacy in all areas; moreover, these areas provide the foundation for academic career success.

Participants appreciated the panelists’ candor and humor. Many commented that much information shared was new to them and provided clarity for their own career journey. They appreciated and were sometimes surprised by the level of authenticity displayed by the presenters and their peers. The openness and empathy of the presenters created a safe, comfortable atmosphere that led many participants to share their struggles and successes. Participants commented that this was a unique feature of this workshop unlike other workshops they had attended in the past.


The Need for Mentors

In the pre-workshop survey, almost all respondents (18 of 19) considered identifying a circle of mentors essential (13) and important (5) for career advancement. Similarly, 17 of 19 participants considered identifying/establishing a peer support network an important professional development objective (tables 2a/b). Respondents were also asked how mentoring, whether present or lacking, influenced their professional success. Participants understood the value of mentoring for their professional development. Many described positive experiences with mentors. Those who did not have active mentors reached out to establish those relationships. Participants of ACW hope to expand their mentoring network with peers and senior attendees. In the post-workshop survey, all participants agreed that the networking opportunities were beneficial, and they plan to invite colleagues identified at ACW to their professional network.


Overall

All participants responded to a post-workshop survey. All participants agreed that: 1) the workshop was a valuable experience; 2) they would recommend the Academic Careers Workshop to their colleagues; 3) they were better prepared to advance their careers as a result of participating; 4) the presenters were responsive to their questions; and 5) the presenters addressed topics that were relevant for their career objectives (table 7). Participants’ post-survey ratings of the workshop were consistent with post sessions survey open responses and participants’ perceptions shared during the focus group sessions. All the participants agreed that attending the Academic Careers Workshop would assist them in the next phase of their career journeys.

ACW was inspirational and provided participants with the knowledge and tools to successfully move forward in their career progressions. Participants often mentioned the content of the sessions was organized, relevant, and in most cases new information. The concrete tips and strategies created many “lightbulb” moments. The sessions were intense, and the materials were dense. The presenters distilled the concepts into manageable nuggets. Participants were at times overwhelmed and yet wanted more. They found the workshop so valuable they wanted more of everything: more networking, more interactive sessions, more time with presenters and peers. A few wanted another day. A scenic tour of the city… All to say many had not experienced a workshop such as this!    



Last Modified: 09/01/2024
Modified by: Valerie E Taylor
